10470053.review:
Much harder and more frustrating than the original Hexcells game but in turn more rewarding when you are able to successfully solve a puzzle. If you want to you can do a bit of guessing with the easier puzzles but that strategy is going to have exponentially diminishing returns as you progress and sound logic is required. Plus, spending a few minutes (or more than a few) trying to figure out the next move before spotting it is sometimes a nice "Ah-ha!" moment. Of all the pure puzzle games that I have played the Hexcells series is the one to which I would most appreciate another edition.

I wish that when developers of other genre games utilize puzzle mini-games as means to hack and crack objects like safes and computers they would implement thought-provoking and challenging puzzles (thought not nearly as challenging as Hexcells Plus) instead of thematically-consistent but boring and uninspired puzzles where the emphasis is on speed rather than true problem-solving. For example, contrast hacking computers in Fallout vs. hacking machines in Bioshock.

I got the original Hexcells in a bundle, and Hexcells Plus on sale for 50% off but even at full price you are going to get your money's worth of challenging puzzles, especially with Hexcells Plus.

10456838.review:
Highly recommend this game. The levels are designed in such a way that you never have to guess; what makes it better is that there are usually multiple avenues towards solving each given level. If you're finding it too difficult to solve one area of (solvable, but tricky) hexes, it's often the case that you can make progress in a separate area before returning with a little more information. 

I would have liked to see some more content, but it was cool how the game kept with the hexagon theme. 6 worlds with 6 levels each. (Though admittedly, a few of the levels were filler / instructional, and didn't pose as much of a challenge.) I wonder if an optional timed mode would be a good idea. On the one hand, it would be nice to come back to the levels in a few months and see how fast I solve them second time around, but on the other hand, the pressure might take away from the uncluttered minimalist feel of the game. 

Overall, thorougly enjoyed Hexcells & Hexcells Plus and would definitely recommend as a stimulating challenge.

10380504.review:
It's a hexagonal Minesweeper, guys, and basically a standalone level pack based on the regular Hexcells – not an enhanced version but "more of the same". Try the regular Hexcells first, see how you feel about it.

The "Plus" version's levels are huge. Unfortunately for me, my brain's pattern recognition breaks there and I start to believe huge levels like these aren't possible to beat purely on logic – I thought there's a couple of levels you need to rely on guesswork to advance, but it would battle against the grain of the game so I'm going to assume I'm the guilty party, not the game. At first some of the levels appeared entirely unbeatable by using logic, but then again a lot of my favourite games incur an initial feel of despair.

One initial gripe of mine was that unlike Minesweeper, there's really no penalty to messing up – you get a score reduction and advancing to the final levels requires a certain amount of points, so you're either puzzling through them like you should, or trial-and-erroring through them and then "beating" them with zero mistakes via memorization or screenshots just to advance to the new puzzles. (I didn't do this.) However, if you play the game fair and square, the pressure to stay frosty and not to mess up during the later stages of a huge level is tangible. Really good.

I initially felt I shouldn't recommend Hexcells Plus at all, but I changed my mind. Get the regular one first, and this after that if you want SUPER HARD MODE levels.

10348469.review: Tek kelimeyle mükemmel. İlk versiyon (Hexcells) çok basitti ama bu versiyonda sonlara doğru zorluk seviyesi güzel bir şekilde artıyor. Hiçbir bölüm imkansız değil, hepsinin mantıklı bir çözümü var. Çok keyif aldım, kesinlikle tavsiye ediyorum.

10344311.review:
I guess I'm all alone here on Steam, but I don't get it. I mean, I get that the puzzles don't require you to guess. That much has been pounded into my head thirty times per discussion board thread. And it's been proven to me to a degree that I accept. Okay. The puzzles don't require you to guess.

...who cares? They're not fun.

I think that the main reason I don't like these puzzles is because if I'm stuck, there's nothing I can really try. What I mean is that the puzzles are completely binary - every space only has two possible choices. So if I'm stuck and I decide that I want to make a guess, I can either guess left click or right click, and my guess is either correct, in which case I know the answer, or it's incorrect... in which case I know the answer. There's no exploration of the puzzle. If I'm stuck in this game and don't want to automatically give myself the answer to the part of the puzzle I'm working on, my only option is to literally just stare at the screen.

Link-A-Pix is a good example of an interesting puzzle because while it only has a single solution, it allows me to try many things without giving parts of the puzzle away to me for trying them. If I'm stuck, I don't have to just stare at the screen - I can try to connect the 9s in one place a different way to make room for something else, or I can pick a different 9 to connect to altogether, or I can even completely erase a small section and redo it to see if it makes room for something I haven't connected yet. Link-A-Pix is not at all binary - when I'm stuck, I can actively search for the solution to a single piece of the puzzle without it being handed to me if that guess is wrong.

Of course, Sudoku is another great (and probably way more popular) example. How many of you guys have come to the end of a Sudoku board and realized "Oh crap, something's wrong here"? That's because Sudoku cleverly gives you options and ways to mess up without giving the answer away if you do mess up. Can you imagine if putting a number in the wrong place revealed to you the right number to put in that place? It would be silly because you wouldn't be able to try anything without parts of the puzzle being handed to you every time you make a mistake. And yet, it also only has one solution, [b]and can even be solved without ever guessing[/b].

With Hexcells, I can't very actively try anything - I can sit and stare at the same material until one little piece jumps out at me, and then I can sit and stare at the same material some more. Spending hours just staring at the same obscure clues over and over again... is just not fun. I don't find the puzzles to be engaging.

I really don't care if you disagree with me. I'm not saying the game was poorly made - like you've all said a million times, the game has logical solutions that do not require you to guess. Okay. I still don't think it's fun. And who seriously recommends a game on Steam that they don't think is fun? I'm not going to do it. I'm not going to pretend that reviewing games is an objective process. No amount of fact can make me like Hexcells, or recommend it to someone. I just simply can't do either one.

So, I guess I'm the lone negative review. UPDATE: Yay, a couple people agree with me, I'm not alone anymore.

Hexcells Plus is an atmospheric puzzle game with really logic levels on which you never have to guess, but cross-analyse clues to make the right decision.

Sometimes you can almost swear you reach the point in a level there are no clues on what to do next, and you'll have to play a dice, but it's just the result of a very well done bunch of intricate puzzles, despite their clean and simple presentation.

You have some different kind of clues and it's variations to deal with, which can be hard and confusing, but the game provides you marker features to help you with it.

For those who know the old Minesweeper, the mechanics of Hexcells Plus are similar, without bombs.

10105460.review:
★★★ out of four.

Hexcells Plus is a simple-enough puzzle game that will get your brain cooking. Minesweeper fit to a hex grid with some additional clues/rules is how this game plays. The basic numbers reveal how many surrounding areas need to be marked, just like Minesweeper. There are also clues for total number along a line of the grid, and the blue hexes tell how many are to be marked within two hexes away. Clues can be clicked to highlight the region they apply to. Around a number, curly braces mean that number is touching/contiguous, while hyphens mean they are not. Throw in only one ambient track, and that is the game. It consists of 36 puzzles which took me 16 hours to "perfect," which seemingly allows one mistake.

It's good this is the case, as the clicking is opposite that of Minesweeper. It can be changed, but I say stick with default for consistency of marking lines and blue hexes, which cannot be changed. Also, when a puzzle is solved, the results screen instantly comes up to cover the puzzle, which limits solving-satisfaction. The game can save three profiles, and for a given Steam Achievement to register the game must be restarted and your profile reloaded.

10090455.review: A great followup to the original game, Hexcells Plus is the same concept, but with a few more advanced puzzle mechanics which makes the game much more difficult. Same number of puzzles as the first one, but will take longer due to the greater difficulty.

10053350.review:
This is a game of patience and logic. It's a fun twist on what is essentially minesweeper and nonograms. There are 36 puzzles in this expansion, and each one has been carefully crafted to always give you enough information to complete without any guessing at all. It took me around 8 hours to solve each puzzle perfectly and unlock all 6 achievements, and I would consider myself to be pretty good at these games.

The later levels will make you sit and think and evaluate every possibility one-by-one. There are even a few times when you'll have to make a connection between two clues, but for the most part you won't go outside the realm of 1 or 2-step logical inferences. If you like logic puzzles, if you enjoy spending half an hour looking at the same thing thinking to yourself "I don't know what to do...", if you want to relax with a calm, quiet brain teaser accompanied by a faint sedate atmospheric audio, or if you just already played the first one and need another set of puzzles to work through, this is the game for you.

Дополнение на порядок сложнее оригинала с самого начала. 10014712.review:
First of all, if you're considering getting this before playing regular Hexcells - don't.  Hexcells Plus is far more difficult than the original and for me, that sapped some of the fun out of it.  I LOVE the original Hexcells and recommend it wholeheartedly.  It's a casual, relaxing little game that introduces you to some new puzzles that will stretch your mind a little by challenging you to think in a new way.  A lot of people compare it to Minesweeper, with the major distinction being that you never have to guess in Hexcells.  You can reach the solution to each puzzle with logic alone.  The difficulty curve on the original is great and most likely the whole way through you're going to have a smile on your face and feel enough of a challenge as new methods are introduced.  Is it going to leave you wanting more?   More than likely.  That's where Hexcells Plus comes in and why I was really looking forward to it.  Did it provide me with more Hexcells? Yes.  Did it give me more of the Hexcells I love? No.  The new puzzle solving techniques introduced in Hexcells Plus, although a logical progression, take it too far.  What the original Hexcells has in common with Minesweeper (other than searching a grid to mark empty and occupied tiles) is an addictive simplicity.  In Hexcells Plus, by making things more complicated to up the difficulty level, some of that charming simplicity is lost and sorely missed.  
Bottom Line - Hexcells Plus is not simply more Hexcells.  It will most appeal, I think, to people who felt the original was too easy.  I thought the orignal was just right.  Hexcells Plus isn't a bad game by any means and I'm happy to support the developer but it's hard not to compare it to the original and be a little disappointed.

9728657.review:
Hexcells took me a couple of hours to unlock and perfect every level. I went straight on to Hexcells Plus...

To give you an indication of the difference in difficulty, Hexcells Plus took me around 20 hours to unlock and perfect every level, without any guides or external assistance. The majority of that time was in a couple of levels in world 5 and a couple more in world 6, which had a particularly large number of hexes to be found - I was going for perfects first time round on every map, so any time I made more than 1 mistake I restarted straight away!

I thought that the step up in terms of difficulty from Hexcells to Hexcells Plus was a good amount. The introduction of an additional mechanic was a nice feature as well.  If I had any issue at all, I'd say that the difficulty could have been ramped up more evenly between each world. 

Would strongly recommend this for a logic/puzzle game fan. As with Hexcells, the interface is crisp, clean and responsive too... so even more reason to give it a go!

I would advise playing through the first game to get yourself up to speed naturally on how all the mechanics work as well, but it's certainly not a requirement to play Plus.

9681457.review:
Bien qu'il rappelle des jeux de réflexion tels que Démineur ou encore Picross, Hexcells Plus se distingue par sa structure hexagonale et ses règles évolutives. Tout comme le Démineur, certaines cellules affichent des chiffres qui correspondent au nombre de cases bleues en contact avec cette dernière. Au fur et à mesure que le jeu progresse, de nouvelles règles s'ajoutent et demandent davantage de réflexion, à l'instar de Picross. Ainsi, la présence d'un chiffre au-dessus d'une colonne, entouré de parenthèses ou de tirets, signifiera que des cases bleues se touchent ou non. Comme il s'agit de l'édition "Plus", la courbe de progression du jeu est plus prononcée et les nouvelles règles compliquent les tâches de déduction, notamment a ajoutant des cases "?", dont on ne peut connaître les contacts. S'il est possible de compléter un niveau en ayant commis des erreurs, les complétionnistes voudront y retourner pour obtenir une note parfaite. Fait à noter, les niveaux où des erreurs ont été commises sont légèrement plus sombres que les autres, ce qui n'est pas très clair. La bande sonore est très apaisante et convient bien au style du jeu. Toutes les énigmes peuvent être complétées en-dedans de 4-6 heures.

Points positifs

+ Jeu de réflexion stimulant et apaisant
+ Règles évolutives maintenant l'intérêt

Points négatifs

- Nouvelles règles complexes, comme l'ajout de "?"
- Affichage des niveaux incomplets trop subtil

9445765.review:
Hexcells Plus is basically a much more difficult version of Hexcells.  It shares the same basic design of a sort of combination between minesweeper and picross, but adds two more hint types: Stacked row hints and area hints.  While the puzzles are much larger and more difficult, they can still be solved without any guessing though it takes a lot more work to do so.  This version has 6 more puzzles than the original, 36 total, and takes much longer to complete.  It took me about 5 times as long as the 30 puzzles in the original to complete without guessing for a total completion time of about 5 hours.

Hexcells is a full, well-crafted puzzle game but I would only recommend the Plus version to people who are very good at logic puzzles or extremely patient.  The difficulty is high enough to be undesirable for some people.

9254558.review:
Mindbogglingly amazing logic puzzles, each intricately crafted to be solvable without guessing. Despite simple interactions (you only need to mark cells black or blue) there are lovable hidden details all over the place. Solve some of one section until you just can't move forward, and that's when you notice that you've uncovered the solution to the other section. As soon as you think you've figured out every trick for a puzzle method, it throws something new at you. It's not the first logic puzzle to offer these, but it does it in so many different and interesting ways. 

You'll be tempted to guess and take the risk of making a mistake. Don't. First off, you're going to make your own mistakes anyway. Secondly, you're spoiling the amazing ways you can solve these puzzles. They are so clever while being completely discoverable. So good that it's worth going back to puzzles you messed up on and figuring out how to get it with no mistakes. 

I generally don't like it when the best way to play a game is with mental rules like this, but Hexcells is so good that I'm so willing to overlook that. Play this game.

9190582.review:
You should take this recommendation as being for Hexcells as well as Hexcells Plus - I bought both elsewhere earlier (hence the near-zero playtime, but it seems to have awarded me the achievements for my progress) and they really should be played together. At least, if you're still interested after the first one, which won't take you long to get through. 

They're both magnificent.

Hexcells is often compared to Minesweeper and that's quite apt (also, Sudoku), but where Minesweeper usually devolves into frustrating guesswork, the puzzles in Hexcells are finely crafted individual pieces that (as far as I can tell) always contain just enough information to solve. So often, when the combination of elements that unlocked some part of the puzzle finally revealed itself to me, I would not just feel the wave of satisfaction at my own accomplishment, but would find myself nodding in appreciation, seeing how carefully that whole side of the board was put together.

And despite Hexcells Plus containing some incredibly tough puzzles (I have one level left to do at the time of writing), perhaps the aspect most worthy of raving about is that they're both such [i]calming[/i] games. The gorgeous ambient soundtrack is...gorgeous, and the developer has enough respect for his puzzles to not add some forced layer of pressure like a time limit. The pace is then whatever you need it to be - for me, the harder puzzles in Hexcells Plus were often a "leave it on all day, have another look at it in half an hour" pace - and I love that. 

Taken together (and they should be, because Hexcells is almost just an introduction to Hexcells Plus), these form a really marvelous little game.

9189212.review:
Regular Hexcells is like super happy fun puzzle time. Hexcells [i]Plus[/i] is the diabolical demon from hell version of the game. It's a whole lot harder than the regular version. There were points where I couldn't find the next logical solution in the puzzle and had to guess. That doesn't mean there wasn't a logical move, just that I couldn't find it! The boards are much bigger and there are added game mechanics that result in more complicated play. It's way more like sudoku, with times when you have make complicated deductions based on the overlap of number clues.

If you want a nice, relaxing puzzle game, buy regular Hexcells. If you want a challenge, grab Hexcells Plus. Better yet, both. I think I slightly prefer regular Hexcells just because I like the more relaxing puzzles, but there is a certain sense of accomplishment to be found in Hexcells Plus that regular Hexcells lacks.

9183454.review:
[I know this shows 0 hours played, but my achievements should prove that I'd previously bought and beaten this game. In fact, I played it three or four times over!]

Hexcells Plus is everything I am always looking for in a puzzle game, distilled to a deceptively simple interface. Though comparisons to Minesweeper are not unwarranted, these comparisons miss a crucial difference: in Minesweeper, the final moves often (and annoyingly) come down to chance, debasing all the carefully planned moves you'd made before should you--at the end of a long game--happen to click a mine.

In Hexcells (and Hexcells Plus), however, the game gives you JUST enough information to never, ever have to guess. But you will often spend many, many minutes searching for and debating your next move. While the game provides various clues as to where you can find Hexes and numbers, it does not (at least past the first few levels) make this obvious (as it is in a game like Picross, for example, where every column's number of squares is provided). It only provides clues for a limited number of columns, rows, sections, etc.; based on this, and based on tricks you'll pick up and teach yourself as you go along, you'll have to very carefully make your next move.

And this is the crucial difference: any mistake you make in Hexcells is your own fault--thus Hexcells corrects an unfortunate norm in the puzzle genre. So, between chess-like demands on your every move, between the security of knowing the game will not force you to guess, between the pleasing visuals and soothing ambient soundtrack, Hexcells Plus is one of, if not THE, best puzzle games I have ever played, and I play many.

5/5

9181747.review:
Like its predecessor, this is the best puzzle game I have ever played. This is more of an expansion than an actual separate game, but the price is so cheap that it doesn't matter.  Both games are worth far more than the asking price, in my opinion.

The music and sound effects are spot-on fantastic, the puzzles are lovingly and painstakingly crafted, and the difficulty progression is just perfect from one puzzle to the next.  Hexcells Plus adds a few things over its predecessor:  additional types of puzzles, a couple of new types of clues, and a bit more difficult end puzzles.

I simply cannot recommend both games enough.

The mechanics are similar to Minesweeper and if you find yourself clicking the wrong mouse button (like me), you can change the button configuration from the Input tab of the configuration menu when you first start the game.  Also, keep in mind that there is never a time that you must guess.

This game makes me feel smart.

EVERY board can be solved without ANY guesses. There is not one time in the entire game you need to hope for luck even if thats incredibly tempting to do with the toughest boards in the game.

Now Ive covered the major complaint many have brought up, Hexcells is a simple reveal the tiles by following the clues game.
Its a really polished puzzler with decent level design, tight easy to grasp rules and a nice difficulty curve, assuming youve played the first game. The only reason I wouldnt recommend buying it is because youd be better off getting the full puzzle bundle it comes in.

Plus, as youd expect, gets quite a bit tougher than its predecessor I could see this being too deep an end to dive in to if you havent played the first game, but it still kept me hooked throughout.
